title: R45869
content: This report provides an overview of FY2019 appropriations actions for accounts traditionally funded in the LHHS appropriations bill, which includes discretionary and mandatory appropriations for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, as well as related agencies like the Social Security Administration. The LHHS bill is a significant source of discretionary funds for domestic nondefense federal programs. The LHHS bill is a major source of discretionary funds for federal programs, particularly in the areas of Labor, Health, Human Services, and Education. It is a controversial bill due to its funding size and social policy issues addressed, such as restrictions on federal funds for abortion and research on human embryos and stem cells. Congressional clients can refer to the LHHS experts list in CRS Report R42638 for information on specific agencies and programs funded in the bill. The LHHS bill provides an overview of FY2019 appropriations, including major congressional actions and funding levels compared to FY2018. The report includes sections on DOL, HHS, ED, and Related Agencies, highlighting key funding differences. Appendix A summarizes budget enforcement activities for FY2019. Appendix A summarizes budget enforcement activities for FY2019, including information on the Budget Control Act of 2011, sequestration, provisional subcommittee spending allocations, and current-year spending levels. Appendix B provides an overview of LHHS-related floor amendments in the Senate for H.R. 6157. The report focuses on appropriations to agencies under the LHHS subcommittees' jurisdiction, excluding funding for other accounts or agencies. The LHHS bill provides appropriations for federal departments and agencies such as the Department of Labor, Department of Health and Human Services (excluding certain agencies funded through other bills), Department of Education, and related agencies like the Social Security Administration and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The LHHS bill includes discretionary and mandatory budget authority for federal departments and agencies like the Department of Labor, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Education, and related agencies. Funding totals in the report do not include amounts provided outside the annual appropriations process. Mandatory programs funded through appropriations are known as appropriated entitlements. Appropriated entitlements are controlled by the authorizing statute, with little control by appropriators over funding amounts. Entitled recipients may have legal recourse if Congress fails to appropriate necessary funds. Mandatory spending is typically provided through the program's authorizing statute, not the annual appropriations process. The funding amounts in the report only include funds provided through appropriations acts. The report focuses on discretionary funding, which receives more attention during the appropriations process. Mandatory spending is subject to budget enforcement processes like sequestration. The President's proposed changes to mandatory spending programs are generally excluded from the report. Sequestration involves across-the-board reductions in discretionary or mandatory spending. Budget authority is the amount of money a federal agency can spend. Appropriations bills may include budget authority for the current or future fiscal years. Advance appropriations refer to funds available in future years. Appropriations levels in the report refer to total budget authority provided in a bill. The report breaks out "current-year" appropriations, measured against 302(b) allocation ceilings. Scorekeeping adjustments are made by the Congressional Budget Office. Appropriations levels in the report do not reflect additional scorekeeping adjustments. Table 1 provides a timeline of major legislative actions for full-year LHHS proposals. Table 1 outlines key legislative actions for full-year LHHS proposals. On July 1, P.L. 116-26 was signed into law, focusing on humanitarian assistance and security at the southern border. The bill included nearly $2.9 billion in emergency LHHS appropriations for the Refugee and Entrant Assistance account at HHS, primarily for the UAC program. The Office of Management and Budget requested $2.9 billion in supplemental funds for the UAC program to increase shelter capacity for unaccompanied alien children apprehended in the United States. The funds would provide critical child welfare services and high-quality shelter care, with designated amounts for state-licensed shelters, post-release services, child advocates, legal services, federal field specialists, and case management services. The bill allocated funds for additional federal field specialists, case management services, and oversight activities to expedite placing children with sponsors and reduce their stay in HHS custody. Conditions were placed on the use of funds, prioritizing community-based residential care and prohibiting funds for unlicensed facilities except in specific circumstances. The bill imposed conditions on the use of funds for unaccompanied children, prioritizing community-based care and prohibiting placement in unlicensed facilities under certain conditions. It also required HHS to ensure certain vulnerable children are not placed in unlicensed facilities and prohibited DHS from detaining sponsors based on HHS information. The bill included provisions on the use of funds for unaccompanied children, prioritizing community-based care and prohibiting placement in unlicensed facilities under certain conditions. It also required HHS to notify appropriations committees of facility assessments and acquisitions, submit discharge rate improvement plans, provide information on unlicensed facilities, and report on children placed at such facilities. The bill required HHS to provide monthly reports on unaccompanied alien children in their care, submit a spending plan within 30 days of enactment, and consider supplemental appropriations for natural disasters. The President signed into law a supplemental appropriations act for FY2019, P.L. 116-20, which included $611 million in emergency-designated LHHS appropriations for accounts at DOL, HHS, and ED. The funds were directed towards expenses related to natural disasters in 2018 and 2019. $201 million allocated to the Public Health and Social Services Emergency Fund at HHS for disaster-related expenses. Additionally, $30 million for Child Care and Development Block Grant, $90 million for Children and Families Services Programs, with specific allocations for Head Start programs, Community Services Block Grant, and Child Welfare Services program. HHS allocated $201 million for disaster-related expenses. HHS directed to transfer funds for behavioral health treatment, federal health centers program, CDC-Wide Activities, and Program Support. The Department of Defense and Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education Appropriations Act, 2019 allocated $165 million for Hurricane Education Recovery at ED to assist in meeting the educational needs of affected individuals. Additionally, the supplemental provided appropriations to the Medicaid program at HHS to support program costs in certain territories. The FY2019 LHHS omnibus appropriations totaled $189.4 billion, with a 1.5% increase from FY2018 and 8.9% more than the President's budget request. The omnibus also included $869.8 billion in mandatory funding, bringing the total LHHS funding to $1.059 trillion. The House Appropriations Committee's LHHS subcommittee approved its draft bill for FY2019 discretionary and mandatory appropriations. The bill would have provided $187.2 billion in discretionary LHHS funds, a 0.3% increase from FY2018 levels, and $869.8 billion in mandatory funding, totaling $1.057 trillion for LHHS. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved the LHHS draft bill on June 28, 2018, with a vote of 30-1. The Senate passed H.R. 6157 on August 23, 2018, containing FY2019 LHHS appropriations. The bill included $189.4 billion in discretionary funds, a 1.5% increase from FY2018. The Senate bill approved $189.4 billion in discretionary funds for FY2019 LHHS appropriations, a 1.5% increase from FY2018 and 8.9% more than the FY2019 President's request. The total combined funding for LHHS was estimated at $1.059 trillion, including mandatory funding. President Trump's FY2019 budget requested $173.9 billion in discretionary funding, a 6.8% decrease from FY2018 levels, and $869.8 billion in annually appropriated mandatory funding, totaling $1.044 trillion for LHHS. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 provided full-year appropriations for all 12 annual appropriations acts, including LHHS. The total LHHS budget for FY2018 was $1.004 trillion, including mandatory funding. The FY2019 Senate bill proposed $189.4 billion in discretionary funds for LHHS, a 1.5% increase from FY2018. The department's entities mainly cover workforce development and worker protection services. The Department of Labor (DOL) administers workforce employment and training programs, including the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA) state formula grant programs, Job Corps, and the Employment Service. They also oversee worker protection services through agencies like OSHA, MSHA, and WHD to ensure worker safety and adherence to wage regulations. Entities focused on worker protection provide services to ensure worker safety, adherence to wage and overtime laws, and contract compliance. The Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics collects data and provides analysis on the labor market. The FY2019 LHHS omnibus included provisions directing the Secretary of Labor to accept private wage surveys for prevailing wages in the H-2B program, exempting certain insurance claims adjusters from overtime protection after a "major disaster," authorizing funding for apprenticeship programs, allowing the employment of law enforcement officers for protection, and granting authority to dispose of excess property as deemed appropriate. The LHHS bill directs funding to multiple HHS agencies, including the Health Resources and Services Administration, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Institutes of Health, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, and Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. These agencies support various health-related missions such as healthcare services, medical research, and disease prevention. The LHHS bill provides funding for HHS agencies focused on healthcare services, medical research, disease prevention, social services, and community supports for vulnerable populations. The LHHS bill provides funding for the HHS Office of the Secretary (OS) for various functions. FY2019 funding levels for HHS increased discretionary appropriations by 2.6% compared to FY2018. The House committee bill proposed a 1.3% increase, the Senate proposed a 2.7% increase, while the President requested a 1.6% decrease in discretionary HHS funding. The majority of funding for HHS goes to CMS for Medicaid benefits and health care trust funds. CMS accounts for 88.6% of all enacted appropriations for HHS. ACF and NIH receive about 4.2% each. Discretionary funding for CMS is 4.9% of HHS appropriations, with PHS agencies receiving 63.5% of discretionary funds. NIH receives the largest share of discretionary funding (41.9%), followed by ACF (25.6%). Public health service agencies receive additional support through HHS-specific funding mechanisms like the PHS Evaluation Set-Aside and the Prevention and Public Health Fund. The PHS Evaluation Set-Aside, authorized by the Public Health Service Act, allows for the redistribution of a portion of eligible program appropriations for program evaluation purposes. LHHS appropriations acts have commonly set a higher maximum percentage for the set-aside and allocated specific amounts of funding to selected HHS programs. Since FY2010, the PHS tap has allocated 2.5% of eligible appropriations to selected HHS programs. In FY2019, there were proposals to increase the set-aside to 2.6% and 2.9%. Annual LHHS appropriations regularly include restrictions on controversial issues. Annual LHHS appropriations acts contain broad restrictions related to controversial issues such as abortions, human embryo research, needle exchange programs, and gun control advocacy. These provisions limit the use of federal funds for abortions to cases where the life of the mother is endangered, in cases of rape or incest, and prohibit discrimination against certain programs receiving LHHS funding. The FY2019 LHHS omnibus bill retained existing restrictions on discrimination against health care entities that do not provide or pay for abortions. A proposed provision based on the Conscience Protection Act was not enacted, which aimed to prevent penalizing or discriminating against health care providers who choose not to perform abortions. Additionally, annual LHHS appropriations have included a provision since FY1996 prohibiting the use of funds for human embryo research. The FY2019 LHHS omnibus bill retained restrictions on human embryo research and needle exchange programs. Funds cannot be used for needle purchase, but can support other program aspects if there is a significant increase in hepatitis or HIV infections. The FY2019 LHHS omnibus bill retained restrictions on human embryo research and needle exchange programs. Funds cannot be used for needle purchase, but can support other program aspects if there is a significant increase in hepatitis or HIV infections due to injection drug use. The program must also operate in accordance with state and local law. Gun control provisions have been included in annual LHHS appropriations since FY1997, prohibiting the use of certain funds for activities advocating or promoting gun control. Restrictions on ACA implementation have been included in annual LHHS appropriations since FY2011. The FY2019 House committee bill included provisions limiting HHS from implementing certain aspects of the ACA. It would have prohibited funds for health insurance "navigator" programs and implementing any provision of the ACA, with limited exceptions. The Senate bill did not have similar provisions. The U.S. Department of Education (ED) was established in 1980 with a mission to promote student achievement and global competitiveness. Three-quarters of ED's discretionary appropriations typically go to local educational agencies for educational and related services. The U.S. Department of Education primarily uses funds to provide educational services for disadvantaged students and Pell Grants for low-income postsecondary students. The federal government contributes 7% of overall funding for elementary and secondary education, while states and local districts provide 83%. For higher education, the federal government provides about 61% of student aid. In AY 2017-2018, the majority of ED's budget is discretionary, with FY2019 enacted levels slightly higher than FY2018. Budget enforcement activities include discretionary spending limits and mandatory spending sequester.
